intro: Monarda tenuiaristata, commonly known as narrowleaf horsemint, is a perennial herb native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the mint family (Lamiaceae) and is characterized by its aromatic, hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces showy, tubular flowers in shades of pink to purple, which attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges and wetlands. Its foliage and flowers are used in traditional herbal remedies and as a source of essential oils.
